BE11:09am

Have HSBC to summarise where we are.

BE11:10am

UK unemployment fell unexpectedly to 4.2% in the three months to February (consensus: 4.3%).
This marks a new 42-year low.
Total pay growth came in below expectations, at 2.8% 3m/yr (consensus: 2.8%). We had been
expecting base effects to lift the annual rate. But regular pay growth rose from 2.6% 3m/yr in
January to 2.8% in February, in line with consensus.
The inactivity rate stood at 21.2%, the joint lowest since comparable records began in 1971.
Likewise, employment at 75.4% has never been higher.
Unemployment had been rising in 3m/3m terms in recent months, but fell again, by 16,000, in the
three months to February (Chart 1).
There were 815,000 job vacancies in March - down slightly but close to the series' all-time high.

chad_john #despitebrexit
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Implications;

BE11:10am

Notwithstanding the disappointment on total pay - which may reflect temporary volatility in bonus
pay - this news increases an already high likelihood that the BoE will raise rates by 25bps to
0.75% at its 10 May meeting. This has been our central case since September. Two members of the
MPC have already started voting for a rise (in March), and given the trade-offs the Bank of
England has been highlighting, the combination of another drop in unemployment and a pick-up in
regular pay growth support their case.
This will be particularly welcomed by the hawks given the weakness in activity data: the BoE
expects GDP growth to slow to 0.3% q-o-q in Q1 2018, while we see an even bigger loss of
momentum (0.2%). Barring an even worse outturn we expect the BoE to attribute most of the
weakness to temporary factors, mainly the weather, while focussing instead on the labour market
strength. The GDP growth number will be published on Friday 27th April.

Pseudonym Surely the country should be wealthy with a 42 yr low in unemployment and yet everyone looks skint...
BE11:11am

It's not clear whether today's total pay disappointment is part of a trend. It may be that firms are being
forced to raise regular pay due to, for example, the national living wage and the fall in net inward
migration, but that this is being offset by lower bonus payments. On the other hand, of course, it may just
be anomalous. The bonus pay data has historically been volatile.
More broadly speaking, we do not share the BoE's optimism on pay growth. We think base effects largely
explain today's rise in regular pay: this time last year, the 3m/yr rate dropped by 0.3ppts. One measure
the BoE has looked at in the past is the 3m/3m annualised rate (Chart 2). This does not persuade us that
much pressure is in the pipeline. It peaked higher in 2014, 2015 and 2016 without leading to any
permanent shift higher in pay growth. Our relative pessimism on wages and underlying inflation
pressures mean we do not expect any further rate rises after May.

BE11:14am

A hawkish print before a May hike: In line with expectations, regular pay growth
accelerated again to its highest rate since 2015, while employment growth was
relatively robust. With the unemployment rate ticking down a tenth to another
40-year low, on the whole we saw the report as marginally more hawkish than
expected. Indeed, the jobless rate now stands below the BoE's estimate of
equilibrium unemployment, at 4.25%. But in our view it's the pay data which is
most significant, as it helps to solidify our and the bank's expectations for labour
market tightness to drive an uptick in homemade inflationary pressures.

Flaneur Pseudo - me neither, but that could be an artifact of High-Street-a-geddon. Didnt someone publish figures that suggest ~90% of new US jobs were 'gigs'?
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Most labour market indicators flashing red: Beyond the headline numbers, we
saw further evidence for sustained labour market tightness. Hours worked
remained close to its recent all-time high, and total vacancies also stayed
elevated, a signal of the difficulty firms are having finding new hires. Meanwhile,
the headline employment rate rose further, to an all-time high, in another sign of
scarce additional labour supply. As we analysed in our recent report on
homemade inflation, there's also limited potential for part-timers to work more
hours.

BE11:14am

Employment remains strong on the year: Although employment growth
weakened slightly on a three-month basis to 55k, it remains solid on an annual
basis (with growth at 427k). On the latest three-month measure, the composition
of employment growth was a little disappointing, with part-time job gains
outweighing those in full-time roles. But we'd caution against reading too much
into one data point. Looking at the past 12 months as a whole, we're actually
encouraged that jobs growth has been mainly driven by gains in full-time
employment. Going forward, we do expect the pace of employment growth to
slow gradually as Brexit-driven uncertainty drives a slowdown in domestic
activity. But with labour supply growth diminished amid reduced inward
migration, some modest slowing in jobs growth remains consistent with BoE
tightening, in our view.

BE11:15am

Homemade inflation drives a hike in May: Today's strong pay data cements our
long-standing call for the BoE to hike rates in May. While recent activity data and
surveys have suggested some slowing in the economy's growth momentum, we
think the MPC currently places less emphasis on this and more weight on
domestically generated inflation. With the labour market remaining at its tights
and pay growth accelerating, we expect continued upward pressure on CPI from
homemade inflation to drive the BoE to hike twice more next ye

BE11:23am

Cenkos incoming:

BE11:23am

Headline trading revenues (of £959m, up 2% YoY) and trading EBITDA (of £391m, down 3%) for FY18 (ending January) are in-line with estimates and guidance; what is more important is that key customer metrics in Roadside remained resilient despite all the second half turmoil, and there was real growth in Insurance. The ongoing strategic transformation is beginning to yield results, guidance on earnings and cash generation was reaffirmed, and debt fears have been allayed. It’s still early days, but with a strengthened board and management team, the AA’s recovery is underway.

In the Roadside division, which combines roadside assistance and driving services, paid Personal Members edged down 1% YoY to 3.29m, and B2B customers edged down 1% to 9.9m, both as signalled earlier. The membership dynamics within both groups point to future growth, with new Personal Members up 7% YoY, and 100% partner retention and a new partner win in B2B. Roadside revenues of £814m (up 1%) were buoyed by B2B customers, where the PAYG economics mean that if breakdowns/callouts rise, so do revenues/earnings.

The ongoing investment in roadside assistance technology is showing results; 1m members have downloaded the app, and it was used in 29% of breakdowns. Combined with the recently-launched Car Genie predictive connected car kit (6,000 vehicles and rising), we think the AA now has a clear technological lead over its rivals that will strengthen loyalty with both B2C customers and B2B OEM partners.

In the Insurance division, revenues were up 11% to £145m and trading EBITDA was up 8% to £71m, with a trading EBITDA margin of 49% (FY17: 50%). Revenue growth was driven by motor insurance broking and the in-house underwriter, with motor policies up 6% to 629k. The introduction of insurance-hosted pricing (IHP) with five motor panel members including the in-house underwriter enabled greater pricing agility which in turn enabled better conversions on price comparison websites; we expect this will continue to boost growth.

Overall guidance on earnings and free cash flow was reaffirmed, with FY19 trading EBITDA of £335-345m and 5-8% growth from FY19 to FY23, and free cash generation of circa £20m in FY19, £80m+ in FY20 and more £100m+ pa thereafter. Combined with S&P’s reaffirmation of the AA’s credit ratings last Friday, and with the next debt repayment of £500m not due until July 2020, there is more than ample time for strong cash generation to allay debt concerns.

In addition to the CEO Simon Breakwell and Chair John Leach, Cathryn Riley’s appointment as a NED brings insurance experience to the board, and at the executive level, Gareth Kirkwood brings experience with BA, telecoms and travel as the new Chief Customer Operations Officer, and Ollie Holden brings experience with Accenture, LV and TalkTalk as the new Chief Information Officer. We think this strengthened board and management team can implement the strategic transformation better, with greater potential for revenue growth.

In short, FY18 performance in-line and guidance reaffirmed, with a stronger management team and a strategy that is beginning to yield results. Trading at a FY20 (Jan) EV/EBITDA of 9.4x and a free cash flow yield of 11%, we reiterate our Buy.

BE11:27am

Jefferies:

BE11:28am

FCF yield trap. The debt to equity swap bull thesis is unchanged while earnings and FCF
momentum has continued to be negative. The normailised FCF yield looks to be 15% but
as this is primarily to be used for de-leverage, the unlevered FCF yield to EV is more relevant
and sits at 6%, not cheap enough in our view given near and medium-term cyclical and
structural pressures on EPS and FCF.
Our Underperform thesis. Estimates look well grounded for this year, both from an
earnings and FCF perspective. However, we continue to see earnings risk from FY20 as we
remain sceptical that initiatives can deliver the 5%-8% group EBITDA growth. In addition,
even returning to "normalised" FCF of £100m per annum, the debt burden of £2.6bn is
unsustainable, in our view.

Sails And French productivity is higher because inflexible job contracts forced their companies to invest more in automation; conversely cheap labour (and more flexible contracts) made UK companies lazier, automation unnecessary - for the moment - and productivity lower

he broker questioned whether Heinz’s culture matches 3G Capital’s tactics of stripping out costs, restructuring supply chains and offering executives big financial rewards for hitting targets. Staff turnover at Heinz has “increased to an alarming level” and graduates are rejecting job offers, according to industry contacts cited by the report.

“We harbour serious doubts about the management team’s ability to generate sufficient product innovation to grow its collection of ‘retro’ brands in highly commoditised categories. The company’s expertise in cost-cutting and price realisation worked well at a time when all of its peers were forced to run the same playbook. But now, with retailers like Walmart and Kroger demanding more from the vendors to drive growth, the playing field has become more competitive.”

On Kraft’s acquisition strategy, Credit Suisse added: “the lack of approachable targets, the reduced buying power of its equity, and the narrow range of options that the board is willing to pursue imply a smaller value for the optionality.”

BE11:43am

Here's the quick summary.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

In this Ideas Engine report, we downgrade Reckitt Benckiser (RB) to Underperform based
on our new in-depth analysis of its top-line growth over the last two years. Using Nielsen data to analyse eight
category/geography cells that represented c40% of RB's developed market sales in FY17, we present evidence of volume
declines being offset by higher selling prices. We are particularly concerned about RB's OTC consumer health business,
noting fewer science-based innovations and increased pressure from generics. On the back of our differentiated analysis,
we assume RB will have to reset pricing/increase investment to revive developed market volume growth/competitiveness.
We reduce our target price to £55.5 from £63.0.
 Lowering estimates: Notwithstanding the boost from a severe flu season in Q1, we now expect RB's developed market
sales to contract this year (with pricing negative) and a 100bp reduction in RB's 'underlying margins' in 2017-19 (all in
developed markets). Our FY19E EPS, which we have reduced by 6%, is now 12% below consensus. In our view, last
year's debt-funded acquisition of MJN (21.5x EBITDA) prevented RB from acquiring the much more synergistic Pfizer
consumer healthcare business.
 Catalyst: We expect management to guide margin expectations lower as we go through the year.
 Risks: Upside risks include newsflow around a potential demerger of RB's Hygiene Home business (which we view as
unlikely at this point).
 Valuation: RB is trading on a FY19E PE of 19.5x (versus the consumer staples sector on 18.5x). We think this is too high,

given the risk that even our below-consensus forecasts have under-estimated the scale of the margin reset (and over-
estimated the pace of margin recovery at MJN). Our grey-sky valuation is £49.

BE11:48am

In our view, the slowdown in RB's top-line is attributable primarily to a relative lack of
successful innovation. Since 2015, there has been a deliberate internal shift in resource
within the portfolio towards the Healthcare brands, where the focus has been on
'disruptive' innovation and a concept termed 'connected health' (we detect less emphasis
on innovation/renovation around the core product portfolio). However, not only did this shift
adversely impact the performance of the Home care brands, but the quality of the
innovation in Healthcare has been disappointing (exemplified in our view by the boom/bust
trajectory of the ill-thought out Scholl/Amope pedi-care innovation).
More concerning to us is that behind this top-line slowdown there is evidence that RB's
developed market business has been losing volume share and trying to compensate by
raising prices faster than competition. In this report, we have used Nielsen data to analyze
eight category/geography cells that we estimate represented c40% of RB's developed
market sales in FY17 (ex MJN). We acknowledge that the Nielsen data does not capture
every channel and that Nielsen tracks retail prices rather than manufacturer selling prices.
We also recognize a risk that the category/geography cells we have chosen might not be
representative. Nonetheless, our analysis suggests that RB will be forced to reset
pricing/increase investment to restore competitiveness and revive volume growth in
developed markets.

Pseudonym The problem with working at the moment is that people are paid such derisory wages it destroys ambition.

Lemmy A. M.: it's unlocking value by demerger
BE11:49am

We are particularly concerned about the top-line slowdown in RB's consumer healthcare
operation (c40% of group profits ex MJN in 2017), noting fewer science-based innovations
and increased pressure from generics. Perhaps as a consequence of a relatively low R&D
spend, the pipeline of new products to which RB can apply its proven marketing skills
appears to be drying up and the IP protection around its existing products dissipating (eg
Mucinex loses important patents in 2020). We estimate RB's consumer healthcare
margins (ex MJN) were 32% last year, significantly higher than those of other comparable
consumer healthcare businesses.

Jonathan Prichard at Peel Hunt's the go-to analyst on plimsole shops. Here's him.

BE11:54am

JD’s FY numbers are ahead of our expectations and the beat was
high quality, coming from a very strong LFL store and online
performance. At a tough time for the industry and the consumer,
that’s a stand-out effort and it is clear that the JD offer is exactly
what the customers want, be that physically or online. Coming as
it does at a moment when the big brands are thinking further
about consolidating their retailer lists, such form is invaluable
and we see the move to the US as another logical step towards
JD becoming a global brand and thus a key partner of the big
suppliers. These are revolutionary times in the industry and its
hard to find a sports retailer playing its cards as well as JD: we
upgrade again today (only small) but from a lowly multiple (even
more lowly if JD gets Finish Line), the shares are a must have for
the short and long term.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We knew that the PBT outcome
would be above £300m so the outcome wasn’t a massive surprise but the nature
of the profit growth is very high quality. LFL in stores was up by 3%, with the
UK in decent positive territory and Europe up in mid single-digits. Online was
the eye catcher (sales up 30% YoY) and overall LFL sales growth was 7% for the
year, implying a very strong H2. JD made a stronger fist this year of the very high
Christmas demand online and that has a few costs consequences but in general
the sales performance was very impressive in what has not been a vintage year for
sports retail: the product innovation hasn’t been great and in general consumers
have been harder to impress. New businesses in Australia and South Korea are
also starting to show good signs (very early in the latter). JD is clearly doing
plenty of things right at the moment.

BE11:58am

A changing world: this supplier support is increasingly important. Top tier
product is crucial to a retailer’s success in this sphere but a reducing list of
retailers are going to have access to it over time as Nike and adidas’ enthusiasm
for DTC shows no sign of waning. Thus impressing these brands with store
formats and increasing volume is massively important and there are not many
retailers doing that at present. Today’s numbers show that customers enjoy the
JD experience and with forecast momentum positive and likely to stay as such,
the early teens multiple for the shares is far too low in our view. A clear Buy.
